text: You choose to remain in Sicily, safeguarding your own realm and expanding in the traditional way.
You choose to go to war with Emperor Otto IV for the crown, though if you succeed the Pope will request that you divest your Sicilian lands.
You decide to refuse the Cumans entry into your lands.
You decide to allow the Cumans to settle.
There is no need for further bloodshed between us, especially when our armies may be tied up elsewhere.
We shall cross the English channel and bring the fight to their lands.
The barons of England are nothing more than another obstacle to French supremacy.
The barons of England will make for a good ally against the English crown.
The King sits in his castle, too worried about his throne to take the fight to the French. The consequences are sure to be known shortly...
The King has spoken - raise the banners, prepare the ships. War has come...
You refuse to sign such an outrageous document! This will surely lead to civil war.
You reluctantly sign the Magna Carta, thereby limiting your powers as king, but appeasing your vassals... for now.
Sack the Vatican, burn it down! Behead the Pope!
It will be better off for our foreign relations to keep the Pope in power despite our grievances with him.
You decide to delay your pilgrimage for five years. This dilemma will be re-issued then.
You decide to delay your pilgrimage for a year. This dilemma will be re-issued then.
You decide against journeying to Mecca, much to the ire of your relatives, and to the outrage of your subjects.
You begin preparations for travel to Mecca.
You choose to forgo the crusade.
You comply with the Pope's demands and forfeit all your gains in the Crusade.
You refuse to comply with the Pope's demands. After all, you did all the hard work!
You decide to push on to Jerusalem, as the Pope promises you will be able to keep your gains if you re-take the city.
You decide to only hand over the crusade's target to the Kingdom of Jerusalem.
By not paying, you will lose the secrets to greek fire forever.
You decide to pay for the replenishment of your greek fire reserves.
By not paying, you will lose the secrets to greek fire forever.
You decide to pay for the restoration of your greek fire reserves.
Assist Toulouse in their war against France.
Assist France in their war against Toulouse, although France may not look kindly upon this assistance, especially if any territory is taken.
Fund a new army for Toulouse.
Stay out of the Albigensian Crusade.
The Golden Bull will be passed.
Refuse to decree the Golden Bull, nobles be damned.
Go to war with the Holy Roman Empire to claim the emperorship for yourself.
The Pope may be angered by this, but claiming the Holy Roman Empire's throne is not in our interest.
You decide to side with the faction1 in this territorial dispute, pleasing them but displeasing the faction2.
You decide to side with the faction2 in this territorial dispute, pleasing them but displeasing the faction1.
You decide to side with neither faction, lowering your imperial authority but avoiding alienating either faction.
You decide to grant the faction1's subject imperial immediacy, increasing your imperial authority but angering the faction1.
You decide against granting the faction1's subject imperial immediacy, decreasing your imperial authority but pleasing the faction1.
You decide to side with the faction1 in this dispute, displeasing the faction2 but gaining imperial authority.
You decide to side with the faction2 in this dispute, displeasing the faction1 but gaining imperial authority.
You decide to side with neither faction, lowering your imperial authority but avoiding alienating either faction.
You decide to side with the faction1 in this dispute, displeasing the faction2 but gaining imperial authority.
You decide to side with the faction2 in this dispute, displeasing the faction1 but gaining imperial authority.
You decide to broker a compromise between the two factions, pleasing both factions with no change to imperial authority.
You ignore both factions' quarreling, pushing forward your own agenda at the imperial diet. Your imperial authority mildly increases without displeasing either faction.
You choose to forgo the crusade.
